repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6750

In `__Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize` handle `bytes`-like objects (such as `const char[:]`) by adding support for [the Python Buffer Protocol]( https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/buffer.html ).

comment_data.body:
Seeing some compile error suggesting `Py_buffer` is unavailable in some builds. Guessing this is related to Python Limited API support. To fix that looks like we want something like this

https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/bf59121ba5c9f79b4bbfeab05407c15e07e4cb15/Cython/Utility/StringTools.c#L767-L799

Looking at that code, it doesn't adapt that well to here. The idea of `__Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize` is to get a pointer to underlying memory in the object. However the other code creates a temporary `bytes` object, whose memory it uses within the lifespan of that temporary. Given `__Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize` has no real way to keep temporary objects (like `bytes`) alive, passing pointers to said temporary objects back to users is UB. So we can't use that

Maybe there are some other options I'm overlooking. Though a simple solution would just be to error in the Python Limited API case

> keep temporary objects (like `bytes`) alive

This also applies to buffers, though. The buffer view is only guaranteed to be usable until we call `PyBuffer_Release()`. After that, the buffer is allowed to become unavailable and should not be used any more.

Buffers need to be handled in place, where and as long as they are used.

Yep agreed, which we do in this code currently

Am more meaning I don't see a good fallback for the Limited API on Python pre-3.11. Though could just be missing alternatives

If you have suggestions, please let me know ðŸ™‚

Or actually does your comment ( https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6750#issuecomment-2744947269 ) mean we should consider moving this code from `__Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize` to the `string.from_py` functions?

Because then we could use the same fallback mechanism

> consider moving this code from `__Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize` to the `string.from_py` functions

Yes. It's safe to do there but not in `__Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize`.

The best general solution is probably `https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/arg.html#c.PyArg_ParseTuple` with `z#`,

If you look at the implementation of that it allows anything that implements the buffer protocol but doesn't specifically have `bf_releasebuffer` (which implies that the buffer is good so long as the object exists). That's "borrowed" but no worse than what we have for bytes.

That's a good suggestion!

Haven't used the `PyArg_*Parse*` functions much before

Tried rewriting this below

Used [`PyArg_Parse`]( https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/arg.html#c.PyArg_Parse ) as it looks like that can take a single value

Also from [the "strings and buffers" section]( https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/arg.html#strings-and-buffers ) used `y#` as it looks like it is limited to `bytes`-like objects where a pointer and size can be returned

Edit: If we wanted to handle unicode `str`s as well, we could use `s#`. If we wanted to handle `None` too, we could use `z#`. Though in the latter case maybe we are better off to define behavior for `None` (if is it important)
Should add was able to test this out locally and it worked ok

Looks like the syntax of the traceback message changes to look more like this

Are we ok with that? If so, can push similar changes to the test suite

Alternatively we can change the error messaging in the function
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -20,7 +20,7 @@ def test_conversion(py_obj):
     True
     >>> test_conversion(123)  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
     Traceback (most recent call last):
-    TypeError: expected ..., int found
+    TypeError: a bytes-like object is required, not 'int'

comment_data.body:
I was generally unimpressed by the performance of the `PyArg_*()` functions and tend to avoid them if possible. Not sure if it makes a difference here, given that the most important cases are already handled up-front and we end up asking the owner to fill our buffer struct etc. These things usually tend to harm smaller data buffers more than larger ones.

If it turns out to be a visible factor, we could try to inline the relevant code for `y#` specifically. Cython has helper macros to look up slots in both the normal and Limited C-API.
We try to avoid also error message changes if it's somewhat reasonable, but usually follow what CPython outputs (at the Python level).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -20,7 +20,7 @@ def test_conversion(py_obj):
     True
     >>> test_conversion(123)  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
     Traceback (most recent call last):
-    TypeError: expected ..., int found
+    TypeError: a bytes-like object is required, not 'int'
